newsitem.title: USA: U.S. interest rate swap spreads soften slightly.
newsitem.headline: U.S. interest rate swap spreads soften slightly.

text.p: Spreads on U.S. swaps softened slightly, but most still held within last week's tight ranges, brokers and dealers said.
"The markets in general are softer, because dealers needed to receive fixed rates due to swap issuance," one broker at a large Japanese bank said.
He said that one Japanese bank bought $200 million of three-year swaps at 21.5 basis points, and said that dealers were receiving three- to 10-year swaps throughout the day.
Another three-year swap traded at 22 basis points on the annual money rate, he said.
Spreads on three-year swaps were quoted at 20 basis points bid, 24 basis points offered.
Spreads on 10-year swaps were quoted at 33 basis points bid, 36 basis points offered.
Several traders noted that overnight one Japanese bank sold $100 million 10-years at 35 basis points to a U.S. bank.

One analyst said several bond issues could be priced this week and possibly widen swap rates this week. He said, however, there was little reaction to Kansai Electric Power's $500 million 10-year bond issuance overnight in London.
Spreads on two-year swaps were at 19 basis points bid, 23 offered, while five-year swaps were at 25 basis points bid, 28 basis points offered.
"The two- to five-year sector represents a lot of value," a dealer at a U.S. bank said, adding that the two-year swap tested a support level at a bid of 13 basis points last week.
